Wesley, you are right that the wording you see in a lot of academic
writing=
 has a political dimension.  :)  The way you frame your
argument and the wa=
y you categorize your ideas can have a dramatic
effect on how and by whom t=
hey are accepted.

Anyway, you are asking how I see things progressing in E=
C in the next
10 years. First, I would not predict with any confidence that=
 EC will
enter into the machine learning mainstream. I just think that it i=
s a
possibility.  But it would be a major cultural shift and I would be
nai=
ve to expect it with any confidence.

However, there is a chance for it to =
happen because EAs do have some
things going for them.  The first factor is=
 mainly a social advantage:
EC is very popular at the grass-roots level com=
pared to other methods
in machine learning.  Many kids in high school have =
heard of EAs or
even used one.  Almost none have programmed Q-Learning or a=
nother RL
method.  In fact, this group is a good example of how accessible =
EAs
are outside the academic community: Many significant contributors to
NE=
AT who have genuinely impacted the field of neuroevolution are not
academic=
s (and in fact post often on this group)!  I think that fact
is remarkable =
when you compare to other areas of machine learning,
where usually only exp=
erts with Ph.D.'s are making significant
contributions.  

The long-term im=
plications of this social phenomenon are yet to be
determined, but I am gue=
ssing it will have an impact as the younger
generation gets to grad-school =
age.  What university is going to meet
their demands?  People are going to =
start filling up the few slots
that are available at the schools that were =
forward thinking enough to
hire in the EC area.  That will put pressure on =
other universities to
follow suit to attract the best students.  So that is=
 one possibility
over the long-term.

Second, I think EAs are a highly prom=
ising research direction in
machine learning at this time.  It is difficult=
 to research issues
such as indirect representation in other paradigms.  EA=
s are in the
unique position of not requiring any explicit gradient informa=
tion and
therefore are free to research radical new ideas much more than e.=
g.
value-function techniques.  I am not saying that such research is
imposs=
ible elsewhere, just that it is easier and more natural in EAs.
 In fact, E=
C research is ahead of RL in the area of representation for
this reason. 

=
Because I believe that representation is at the heart of artificial
intelli=
gence, I think there's a reasonable chance that the advantage
of researchin=
g representation will start to bear fruit in the next 10
years.  At that ti=
me, the gap between what EC can do and what RL can
do will start to widen a=
nd it will become difficult to ignore EC in
the mainstream.

So I think the=
 social advantage plus the research advantage together
suggest a promising =
future.  Of course, prognostication like this is
pure speculation, so like =
I said, don't hold me to it.  I am not
saying any of this with confidence. =
 I would not count any fields
(such as RL) out because like I said before, =
the best way to view a
field as a researcher is not to see if for what it h=
as or has not
accomplished so far, but for what it might accomplish in the =
future,
and it is very difficult to make predictions in that spirit outside=

one's own expertise.

ken
